content.description: nice crimps and crux is in the middle. Starts as low as you want. I found a nice foot underneath the roof and two nice crimps to start on
content.location: Walk along the east side of the creek along the trail that starts at the bridge. You should see trail clearly marked. Walk all the way down past the first waterfall. You should see a sport wall which is directly behind the boulder

content.description: Surmount the roof that starts straight off the ground. Commit to a good undercling to gain the slab with a crack in it. Chuck a piece of gear in if you can find a placement. I gave it PG-13 because if you can’t find a placement here, the next good gear isn’t until you continue up to find a great horizontal crack at 15-20 feet up. From here continue up towards the short dihedral. The crack in the dihedral takes nuts and passive gear well. Layback and stem your way up the dihedral, and find a dirty ledge up high that allows you to exit the dihedral. Continue up using roots and whatever else you can find to top out. Also, not sure what the name of this route is, but if anyone has more info, I’m happy to update it.
content.protection: For leading: Bring a full set of standard nuts and tricams. A black diamond number 1 camalot slots very nicely in the final pocket at the top.For Top Rope: Walk around to the top and set up an anchor off of the large tree just to the side of the dihedral.
content.location: From frosted flake, walk 20 or so feet to the right. There is a very obvious dihedral with a crack in it.

content.description: Previously listed as "unnamed variations 9-11"Start on juggy laybacks, follow the layback up until the holds run out. Move onto the crimps with smeary feet. Big throw and match onto a sloper (crux) and mantle out of that. Follow that line of sloping holds into another powerful mantle and high five your belayer when you top out at the anchor.
content.protection: Set up top rope off the large trees set back from the cliff. A 3-in-1 system actually works great here since you can hang the first anchor points off the roof slab set a ways back from the cliff and be anchored off the instructor tether.  Belay from the topl
content.location: Lover into the stream bed from the TR anchor and begin up the most obvious route of juggy laybacks.

content.description:
Great moderate climb.    Crux is the undercling traverse.  

  Flake is often wet, but holds are juggy and super positive.
content.protection: Set top rope off trees back from the cliff, do not use the old chains.
content.location: Starts at the base beneath an obvious undercling flake. Climb the most direct line then traverse the flake and top the climb above said flake.

content.description:
Quieter crag away from the Rim road area. Shaded and cool due to the waterfall/creek nearby.   It's not geographically far from the Main area, but the permanently closed road makes the driving trip longer.  

  This area has traditionally been left as more of an adventurous area, and there are plenty of lines awaiting more traffic.  The rock is good, similar to the Rim road area, but dirtier due to few people going there.
